awd_titl_txt: DMREF: Collaborative Research: Accelerating Thermoelectric Materials Discovery via Dopability Predictions
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Description: Thermoelectric devices, which transform heat flow into electrical power and vice versa, have the potential to revolutionize how society produces electricity and cooling.  However, thermoelectric materials suffer from poor power conversion efficiency and the search continues for new materials with enhanced performance. In this project, advances in computation and machine learning are leveraged to accelerate this search for advanced thermoelectric materials. These efforts build upon the prior NSF DMREF research of some of team members on predicting a material's potential for thermoelectric performance. High throughput screening focused on identifying semiconductors with desirable electronic and vibrational properties.  However, these efforts did not include a strong focus on the role of intrinsic defect or the potential for dopability.  In the next stage of this research, these critical components will be pursued through a mixture of high throughput theory, experimental validation, and machine learning.  Together, these efforts will yield accurate prediction of the thermoelectric potential for thousands of semiconductors and the realization of new materials for solid state power generation.  Beyond thermoelectric materials, these efforts to establish a dopability recommendation engine will be critical in the development of next generation microelectronic and optoelectronic materials such as transparent conductors and photovoltaic absorbers.   

Technical Description: The project's ultimate objective is to build a robust and accurate dopability recommendation engine to overcome the dopability bottleneck in thermoelectric materials discovery. The recommendation engine will use materials informatics to enable high-throughput predictions of dopability, relying only on quantities that are inexpensive to calculate, experimental measurements, and known structural/chemical features as inputs. It will thus allow dopability screening of thousands of compounds.  First, an accurate training set will be built for the recommendation engine containing native defect formation enthalpies and structural/chemical descriptors from a diverse array of thermoelectric-relevant compounds. Whereas prior dopant studies focused on single compounds, a new, automated calculation infrastructure will be leveraged that allows the rapid creation of an extensive training set, initially containing approximately 30 compounds but growing to over 100 during the project. Experimental charge transport and local dopant structure measurements will validate the training set. Second, the prediction engine will be trained on the data to extract patterns and correlations, and ultimately identify robust descriptors of dopability.  Initially, the engine will predict if `killer' defects limit the available dopant range. The engine will ultimately grow to suggest specific extrinsic dopants for compounds that pass this initial screening.  Together, this combination of accurate predictions of intrinsic transport properties (prior DMREF) and dopability (proposed DMREF) is expected to accelerate the discovery process for thermoelectric materials.

por.por_cntn:
Many emerging technologies require the discovery of new semiconducting materials whose physical properties can be precisely tailored to gain control over electrical conductivity. Precise control over conductivity in materials are needed to enable technologies such as thermoelectrics, power electronics, batteries, and many others. Although it has long been known that the type and quantity of defects present in a semiconductor govern its electronic properties, historically the discovery of new semiconductors has remained a slow process, hindered by the trial-and-error nature of experimental work to optimize defect composition for a given application.

     To overcome these barriers, this project targeted accelerated discovery of new semiconductors with controllable defect chemistry, through a novel approach to computation-guided experiment that allows linking materials simulations, experimental synthesis, and experimental characterization. The project has demonstrated the application of computational methods to predict synthetic strategies to control the carrier concentration in candidate thermoelectric materials through a combination of native defect control and extrinsic doping strategies.  Key developments in phase boundary mapping synthetic techniques to link theory and experiment, growth techniques controlling doping, resonant X-ray diffraction techniques used to characterize local defect structure, and computational methodologies for describing structure in disordered semiconductors and dopability predictions have resulted from this effort. These developments demonstrate that computation-guided experimental strategies can accelerate the search for new, highly dopable semiconductors with precisely tailored defect composition and electronic conductivity.

     The computation-guided experimental paradigm demonstrated through this effort has resulted in key insights across a diverse set of emerging complex semiconductors. For instance, (i) the thermoelectric potential of a large class of ordered-vacancy chalcogenides (OVCs) was investigated using computational screening, and validated by synthesis and characterization. To explore the search space of unreported OVCs, a computational workflow based on quality factor, stability, transport and defect assessment to screen candidates from hypothetical structures generated from chemical substitutions on structure prototypes was developed (Figure 1). This workflow resulted in the identification of unknown stable OVCs predicted to yield high TE performance. Experiments corroborated the prediction by successful synthesis and electronic measurement. In the most promising OVC, Hg2GeTe4, a detailed computational/experimental survey of potential dopants (17 elements considered) revealed the accessible ranges of carrier concentration. This ordered vacancy compound is predicted to achieve high p-type carrier concentrations with Ag and Au, and  while intrinsic Hg vacancies were predicted to prevent successful n-type doping. (ii) The root causes of the high thermoelectric performance in complex Ge1-xMnxTe alloys by combining experimental and computational efforts. We find that Mn content has a significant impact on the crystal structure, electronic band structure, electron and phonon scattering in this alloy system. We conclude that band convergence, moderate effective mass, and favorable transport properties enable Ge1-xMnxTe alloys with compositions near the phase transition to exhibit good thermoelectric properties.

     To streamline defect-related analyses of a material, a software for visualizing the native and extrinsic defect formation energetics from DFT calculations called the "Visualization Toolkit for Analyzing Defects in Materials" (VTAnDeM) has been developed and made available to the user community. The interactive user interface allows synchronous visualization of the stability -- defect -- carrier concentration phase space in real time. As a result, the defect energetics and resulting carrier concentration can be visualized for each thermodynamic condition under which the parent material is stable, allowing direct aid towards experimental efforts such as phase boundary mapping.

     Key outcomes of this program include: (i) development of a robust knowledge base of defect calculations and experimental measurements of structure and transport for accelerating thermoelectric discovery, (ii) creation of a feedback loop between dopant calculations, thermoelectric material synthesis, and characterization of structure and transport properties, (iii) training the next generation of scientists in multi-disciplinary science through workshops and summer schools, and (iv) the generation of  computational data and experimental samples that are findable, accessible, interoperable, and reusable (FAIR) and software/visualization tools to analysis of the defect properties of complex multi-component semiconductors.
